intro: Papaver rhoeas subsp. rhoeas, commonly known as the common poppy, is a flowering plant native to Europe, western Asia, and North Africa. It is characterized by its striking red, papery petals and a prominent, centrally located seed capsule. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–90 cm, with a taproot and alternate, lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found along roadsides and in fields. The flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
